questions.text: A drug sensitivity test of a patient's sputum sample shows the presence of vancomycin-resistant MRSA. A narrow-spectrum protein synthesis inhibitor antibiotic that inhibits the formation of formylmethionine-tRNA 70S initiation complex was started for the patient. Which drug was most likely used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Linezolid

Explanation:

In the above scenario, the patient's sample shows the presence of vancomycin-resistant MRSA, a multi-drug-resistant strain for whom linezolid is reserved.

  • Linezolid is a narrow-spectrum protein synthesis inhibitor that targets only gram-positive bacteria.
  • Mechanism of action: Inhibition of the formation of the formylmethionine-tRNA 70S initiation complex, thus preventing the initiation of protein synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding Chloramphenicol?

choices.text: It is metabolised via hepatic conjugation
It can cause dose-dependent marrow suppression
It can be safely used in neonates
Resistance occurs due to plasmid-mediated inactivation by bacteria.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It can be safely used in neonates

Explanation:

Chloramphenicol should be avoided in neonates due to their immature liver, which leads to toxicity. This results in "grey baby syndrome," characterised by hypotonia, distended abdomen, irregular respiration, ashen grey cyanosis, elevated lactic acid levels, cardiovascular collapse, and potentially death.

Category

Description

Mechanism of Action

Inhibits protein synthesis by blocking the 50s ribosomal subunit, preventing peptide chain elongation.

Absorption & Distribution

Rapidly absorbed, has a high volume of distribution (1 L/kg), has good CSF penetration, and freely penetrates bodily cavities.

Excretion

Excreted via hepatic glucuronidation. (Option A)

Drug Interactions
  • Inhibits metabolism of warfarin, cyclophosphamide, and phenytoin.
  • Enhanced metabolism by phenobarbitone, phenytoin, and rifampin.

Resistance Mechanisms

Plasmid-mediated inactivation by bacteria decreases penetration into bacteria. (Option D)

Uses

Second line for pyogenic meningitis, endophthalmitis, anaerobic infections

Side Effects
  • Dose-dependent marrow suppression. (Option B)
  • Dose-independent idiosyncratic reaction.
  • Hypersensitivity.
  • Grey baby syndrome.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man with a history of multiple sexual partners comes to the clinic with an inguinal swelling. Physical examination findings are given below. What would be the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Doxycycline

Explanation:

Lymphogranuloma venereum is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, and the drug of choice is Doxycycline + Azithromycin.

Doxycycline is a member of the tetracycline group. It is a protein synthesis inhibitor that blocks 30S mRNA-ribosome, thus inhibiting the attachment of aminoacyl-t-RNA to the acceptor (A) site.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman was treated with an antibiotic for chlamydia during-her 6th month of pregnancy. Nine months later, she delivered a healthy baby boy. As the child grew, he developed teeth resembling those in the provided image and had a short stature. Which antibiotic was most likely used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tetracyclines

 

Explanation:

  • Tetracyclines are contraindicated in pregnancy, lactation, and children due to the risk of calcium-tetracycline chelation, which can lead to permanent yellowish discolouration of teeth and inhibited bone growth.
  • It should also be avoided with dairy products as they reduce drug absorption.
  • Contraindication of tetracycline :
    • Pregnancy
    • Children
    • During lactation
    • Renal failure (Except Doxyxline)
  • Adverse effects of tetracycline are:
  • Acute hepatic necrosis: seen in pregnancy
  • Fanconi syndrome
  • Photosensitivity
  • Permanent discolouration of teeth (due to in-utero exposure)
  • Delayed growth
  • Diabetes insipidus
  • Rarely, ↑ ICP in children/pseudotumor cerebri
  • Vestibulotoxic (minocycline)
  • Exfoliative dermatitis (hypersensitivity reaction)

Amikacin (Option B) is also contraindicated during pregnancy due to potential ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity, but it does not affect bone growth or tooth colour.

Chloramphenicol (Option C) is contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risk of 'grey baby syndrome', which can lead to severe symptoms like hypotonia, distended abdomen, cyanosis, and cardiovascular collapse.

Sulfonamide (Option D) is a sulfa drug that displaces bilirubin from albumin, leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which leads to kernicterus. Thus, it should be avoided during pregnancy and in neonates.

questions.text: Which of the following antimicrobials is safe for use in neonates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Azithromycin

Explanation:

Azithromycin is considered safer for use in neonates. It is often used in neonates to treat infections such as chlamydia conjunctivitis and pneumonia.

Azithromycin 

Mechanism of Action

Azithromycin inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit, interfering with the elongation of the polypeptide chain and ultimately halting bacterial growth.
Pharmacokinetics
  • Excellent intracellular penetration, allowing it to effectively target intracellular pathogens. This intracellular accumulation contributes to its prolonged half-life.
  • Once-daily dosing
  • Hepatic clearance
  • does not cross the blood-brain barrier.

Common Uses
  • Respiratory Infections (e.g., pneumonia (atypical), bronchitis)
  • Genitourinary Infections (e.g., Chlamydia trachomatis)
  • Skin and Soft Tissue Infections (e.g., cellulitis)
  • Other Infections (e.g., otitis media, pharyngitis)

Side Effects
  • Mild gastric upset
  • Abdominal pain
  • Headache
  • Dizziness

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics is commonly used in triple therapy to treat H. pylori infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Clarithromycin

Explanation: 

The triple therapy regimen for H. pylori you provided is as follows:

  • Lansoprazole: 30 mg
  • Amoxicillin: 1000 mg
  • Clarithromycin: 500 mg

Aspect

Clarithromycin

Mechanism of Action

Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit.

Uses

Upper and lower respiratory tract infections, otitis media, whooping cough, atypical pneumonia, H. pylori eradication, MAC infection in AIDS patients, other atypical mycobacterial diseases, and leprosy.

Side Effects

Gastric intolerance, reversible hearing loss (at high doses), hepatic dysfunction, rhabdomyolysis (rare), and CYP3A4 inhibition lead to potential drug interactions.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Erythromycin?

choices.text: Erythromycin is stable in an acidic environment.
Have a large volume of distribution, allowing for extensive tissue penetration.
Highly lipid-soluble, allowing for excellent penetration into the central nervous system

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Have a large volume of distribution, allowing for extensive tissue penetration.

Explanation:

  • Erythromycin distributes widely into most tissues (lungs, prostate, macrophages, etc.) except the CNS, reflecting a large volume of distribution (Vd).
     
  • It accumulates intracellularly and achieves therapeutic levels in various tissues, supporting its use in respiratory and soft tissue infections.
     

Pharmacokinetic features of erythromycin:
 

Property

Details

Volume of distribution

High, with extensive tissue penetration

Acid stability

Unstable in acidic pH (why enteric-coated or esterified forms are used)

Route of excretion

Mainly hepatic, via bile

CNS penetration

Poor, due to limited lipid solubility


Primarily eliminated through renal excretion (Option A): Incorrect because erythromycin is excreted via the bile, not primarily by the kidneys.
 

Erythromycin is stable in an acidic environment (Option B): Incorrect because erythromycin is acid-labile, which is why formulations like erythromycin estolate or enteric coatings are used.
 

Highly lipid-soluble, allowing for excellent penetration into the central nervous system (Option D): Incorrect because erythromycin does not penetrate the CNS well and is not highly lipid-soluble.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with severe diarrhoea and abdominal pain after recently being treated with an antibiotic for a skin infection. Stool tests confirm the presence of Clostridium difficile. Which of the following antibiotics is associated with the highest risk of causing pseudomembranous colitis in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Clindamycin

Explanation:

The antibiotic most commonly implicated in causing pseudomembranous colitis is Clindamycin.

Clindamycin

Mechanism of Action

Inhibits protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosome.

Spectrum of Activity

Effective against gram-positive cocci, Clostridium spp., Nocardia, Actinomyces, Toxoplasma

Use

Anaerobic and mixed infections, especially those caused by Bacteroides fragilis, can lead to conditions like abdominal and pelvic abscesses, lung abscesses, septic abortion, and infections from penetrating injuries.

Adverse Effects
  • Rashes, urticaria, abdominal pain.
  • Liver damage
  • Thrombophlebitis at the injection site.
  • Major concern: Pseudomembranous enterocolitis due to Clostridium difficile superinfection, potentially fatal.

Erythromycin (Option A), Tetracycline (Option B), and Ciprofloxacin (Option D) are less commonly associated with pseudomembranous colitis than clindamycin.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with renal failure presents with a suspected Gram-positive bacterial infection. The patient's creatinine clearance is significantly reduced. Which antibiotic would be the most appropriate choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Linezolid

Explanation:

Linezolid is the preferred choice for this patient due to its hepatic metabolism and non-renal excretion, which enhances safety in individuals with renal impair

Linezolid

Mechanism of Action
  • It inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 23S ribosomal RNA of the P site of 50S ribosomal subunit.
  • It interferes with the formation of the ternary N-formylmethionyl-tRNA (tRNAf-Met)-70S initiation complex, preventing the initiation of protein synthesis.

Spectrum of Activity
  • Gram-positive cocci (aerobic and anaerobic): MRSA, VRSA, VRE, Strep. viridans, Strep. pneumoniae
  • Other sensitive bacteria: Clostridia, B. fragilis, M. tuberculosis.

Common Uses
  • Uncomplicated and complicated skin and soft tissue infections Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAPs)
  • Bacteremia.

Side Effects
  • Mild abdominal pain, nausea and diarrhoea.
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Optic neuritis
  • Bone marrow suppression (monitor platelet count)
  • Caution is advised when used concurrently with MAO inhibitors due to the risk of serotonin syndrome.
  • Serotonin syndrome

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with diabetes and chronic kidney disease is hospitalised for a severe diabetic foot infection, likely due to MRSA. The doctor is considering a Streptogramin antibiotic. Which of the following statements about Streptogramins is correct?

choices.text: Inhibit bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit.
Cover both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria.
The most common adverse effect is nephrotoxicity.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Streptogramins inhibit bacterial protein synthesis through binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit.

Explanations:

  • Streptogramins (e.g., quinupristin-dalfopristin) are bacteriostatic agents that work by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit.
     
  • This binding inhibits protein synthesis and results in a synergistic effect, making the combination bactericidal against many Gram-positive organisms.
     
  • They are used in multi-drug-resistant Gram-positive infections, especially MRSA and vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecium.
     

Streptogramins:

 

Feature

Details

Mechanism of Action

Inhibit protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit

Examples

Quinupristin-Dalfopristin (used in fixed combination)

Spectrum of Activity

Mainly Gram-positive cocci (MRSA, VRE faecium)

Adverse Effects

Phlebitis, arthralgia, myalgia, elevated bilirubin (not nephrotoxicity)

Excretion

Primarily hepatic (safe in renal dysfunction)

 

Cover both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria (Option B):
Incorrect. Streptogramins have no significant activity against Gram-negative organisms, especially due to efflux pumps and enzymatic resistance.
 

First-line therapy for community-acquired pneumonia (Option C):
Incorrect. Streptogramins are not first-line; macrolides, fluoroquinolones, or beta-lactams are preferred. Streptogramins are reserved for resistant Gram-positive infections.
 

The most common adverse effect is nephrotoxicity (Option D):
Incorrect. Streptogramins are not nephrotoxic. Common side effects include phlebitis, arthralgia, and myalgia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic man presents with a severe UTI, showing high fever, chills, and dysuria. Urine culture reveals E. coli resistant to aminoglycosides and fluoroquinolones. What mechanism likely contributes to E. coli's resistance to aminoglycosides?

choices.text: Inactivation of the drug by bacterial enzymes
Alteration of the bacterial ribosomal binding site
Decreased uptake of the drug into bacterial cells
Formation of biofilms on mucosal surfaces

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Inactivation of the drug by bacterial enzymes

Explanation:

  • Aminoglycoside resistance typically involves modification by bacterial enzymes like acetyltransferases, phosphotransferases, and nucleotidyltransferases.
  • These enzymes alter aminoglycosides, preventing their binding to bacterial ribosomes and blocking protein synthesis.
  • This resistance mechanism is common in multidrug-resistant bacteria, including those causing urinary tract infections (UTIs).

Aminoglycosides

Mechanism of action

Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit, causing misreading of mRNA.

Drugs

Streptomycin, Gentamicin, Tobramycin, Amikacin, Neomycin, Netilmicin

Spectrum

Primarily Gram-negative aerobic bacteria; limited Gram-positive coverage. Includes Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Enterobacteriaceae.

Uses
  • Serious Gram-negative infections (e.g., sepsis, pneumonia)
  • Tuberculosis (Streptomycin)
  • Endocarditis (Gentamicin in combination therapy)

Resistance mechanism
  • Enzymatic inactivation by acetyltransferases, phosphotransferases, and nucleotidyltransferases.
  • Alteration of the 30S ribosomal binding site.

questions.text: Which adverse effects are most commonly associated with aminoglycosides?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity

Explanation:

Adverse Effect

Mechanism of Action

Reversibility

Risk Order

Ototoxicity
  • Damages hair cells (neurons projecting into endolymph).
  • Cochlear damage leads to high-frequency hearing loss.
  • Vestibular damage leads to imbalance, ataxia, vertigo.

Irreversible.

Neomycin > Amikacin > Kanamycin.

Nephrotoxicity

Damages tubular cells of nephron (PCT, DCT), leading to renal tubular acidosis.

Reversible.

Neomycin > Gentamicin > Streptomycin.

Neuromuscular Blockade
  • Inhibits release of ACh and blocks Nm receptor, leading to muscle paralysis
  • Contraindicated in Myasthenia gravis

Partially reversible with calcium salts.

Neomycin > Streptomycin > Tobramycin.

questions.text: Which antibiotics will be least helpful in treating Enterococcus faecium infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ampicillin

Explanation:

Ampicillin inhibits cell wall synthesis by binding to PBPs. However, it is least effective against E. faecium strains due to resistance caused by altered PBPs.

Drugs useful in Enterococcus infection:

Drug

Mechanism of Action (MOA)

Vancomycin

Inhibits cell wall synthesis by binding to the D-alanyl-D-alanine terminus of cell wall precursor units.

Linezolid

(Option B)

Inhibits protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit.

Daptomycin

(Option C)

Causes rapid depolarisation of bacterial membrane potential, inhibiting protein, DNA, and RNA synthesis.

Nitrofurantoin

Reduced by bacterial enzymes to reactive intermediates, altering or inactivating bacterial ribosomal proteins.

Tigecycline

(Option D)

Inhibits protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with COPD develops severe diarrhoea, abdominal cramps, and fever two weeks after being treated with ceftriaxone and clindamycin. Stool testing confirms Clostridioides difficile infection. An endoscopic image shows pseudomembranous colitis. Which antibiotic is the most appropriate for treating her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fidaxomicin

Explanation:

  • Fidaxomicin is the best choice for treating severe pseudomembranous enterocolitis caused by Clostridioides difficile.
  • It specifically targets C. difficile, minimising disruption to the gut microbiome and reducing recurrence risk compared to broad-spectrum antibiotics like metronidazole or vancomycin.
